ratings.comment: All exam content was covered in lecture. Practice problems were very helpful for exams. No notecards for exams, but there is an index guide for the exam. Just a hard class.

You need to spend some extra time after class on problem sets to get practice on the dense content covered in class in a short amount of time. But Dr. Stowe has no control over that because this is a departmental decision

Dr. Stowe himself is very, very nice-he is extremely friendly during his office hours and always encourages you to think deeply

You can really tell that Ryan is an expert in his field and highly knowledgable and passionate about organic chemistry, but unfortunately that doesn't translate well for people who are learning the subject for the first time. A lot of class is spent on tophat questions that didn't feel too productive. Answer keys were almost never fully completed

Dr. Stowe is a professor who is passionate about ochem. However, he speaks a little too fast for me to understand and he falls behind quickly with his tophat questions. I would recommend Dr. Stowe if you are also passionate about ochem but if you are not, I would not recommend.

Don't go to his lectures, don't read the textbook, just watch Esselman's videos instead. Ryan wastes TONS of times on useless TopHat questions. Very fast paced, and always fall behind due to these TopHat time wastes. Not available over Piazza, so don't chose him unless he is with Esselman/Anzovino combo lecture.

Ryan is very sweet and passionate about his teaching. He is good at breaking things down but you have to ask him specifically, he wont do it on his own. Says at the start of the semester that you don't need to put buzz words in explanations, THATS A LIE!!!! Buzz words is the only thing you will get points for.

Dr. Stowe is definitely passionate about what he teaches. He is a fun guy, and true nerd and genius in chemistry (which means his lecture can be fast pace and a little bit unclear). Overall a good professor, would recommend.

Dr. Stowe clearly cares about Ochem and how he he teaches it. He spends a lot of time on TopHat but is more than happy to answer questions both in and out of class. He's also just a really nice dude:))
slay ryan, he is so nerdy. loves ochem a lot. he is good. take his class.

3 stars come Stowe's obvious passion. He's genius of all things O'Chem. That said, if you are looking for digestible, clear-cut instruction, I would avoid his class. Watching old Esselmen lectures is carrying me. I leave Stowe's class more confused than when I got there. Dr. Stowe needs to be less technical if he wants to reach all of his students.

Definitely would recommend. Strives to make sure all students understand what is going on before just flying through content. A lot can be learned from lecture in terms of chemical reasoning, which is a lot of what is on exams.

If you're a chem major passionate about learning the why behind things Professor Stowe is a great option. If you need to take OChem as a requisite and are looking for a decent grade, there are probably better options. I enjoyed the deep dives into specific concepts and the clicker questions helped digest content, but took too much time.

Okay so Prof. Stowe is clearly a well-educated guy, but he spends too much time on his TopHat that only his lecture class will do. If he ends up writing the exam for that period of the semester, odds are that in-depth applications of his lectures will be on the exam. Do the problem sets, but you don't need the textbook; khan academy helps a lot.

Dr. Stowe can fall behind the rest of the trio in lecture which can be frustrating. However, this also means he skips over obscure stuff that won't be on exams. Excellent at explaining stuff in office hours and piazza. My understanding is his research is actually in chemistry education which is why he sometimes experiments with his lecturing style.

I truly do want you all to take 345 with different professors, other than him. Test heavy, he wants you all to act and work like a PhD or sth, test hardest questions every time. He wants you to memorise every single stuff of OChem, no cheat sheet available, which are meaningless because in real world's office, no one does it like that!
absolutely horrible. very pretentious and does NOT explain things well. 0/5 would never take his course again. 343 was a nightmare with him.

O-chem is just a hard class to teach. Stowe is a very nice professor and his lectures are fairly slow paced. The problem with this is that sometimes he wont finish the material before the quiz so youll have to watch the remaining lecture online or just self teach. Overall tho, very solid choice. p.s :Clicker questions are a waste of time

He expected students to 100% understand material immediately after lecture. Many students that asked for help were met with statements insulting our intelligence. I found out later in the course that the students succeeding in the course were skipping his lectures for other 343 professors, as they lectured at a undergraduate level, not doctoral.

I had Stowe for Chem 343 & 345. Solid choice. Lectures are very thorough and he encourages students to ask questions and interrupt lecture. It takes a lot of dedication to do well in O Chem. Practice quizzes and tests are provided to help study. Stowe is easy to approach after lecture and TAs are a great resource. Go to discussion!!

For a course that will be extremely hard no matter who you have, I'd say Stowe is one of the better professors. He's very thorough in lectures, and the discussions were helpful. Exams were of course very difficult, but practice exams were provided so you knew what you were expected to know.

Professor Stowe is a solid lecturer. He's part of a group of three professors that have all the same problem sets, lectures, and exams. Chem 343 is a super hard class, but there are lots of resources. If you put the time in, you can do well. Stowe is clear and hammers home points about energy and reactivity that are important to for exams.
Hard class. Tough material. You won't get much out of it if you don't prepare before and review after lectures. If you are willing to work, he is a good choice.
He is a fine choice for 343. Explains everything well, but goes fast. Super nice and accessible outside of class and very prompt and helpful.

I thought he was really funny and there were a lot of resources for an especially hard class. If the resources aren't working I found office hours were really helpful for more specific and deeper explanations. Reading the book is also crucial because most of lecture is examples.

Stowe seems like a nice guy, but his lecturing skills are mediocre. He tries to be funny at least. He teaches a tough subject, but this semester he was with other very good professors, so the class was doable. Do the problem sets. Absolutely use TA office hours. TAs taught me most of what I learned. Grade is based on 3 quizzes, 3 exams and a final.
He just gave the same lecture that was recorded the semester prior but left out many important explanations. However, resources from 3 profs were given so if you wanted a good grade, it was possible.

Stowe is nothing compared to Bohman, Esselman or Ellisen. I get this was his first year but in office hours when asking about where electrons go in orbitals his response was "you just have to know." Not only person who had this problem. Take Esselman if you can!

Ryan Stowe taught with UW's best o chem professors, Esselman & Elisen. Stowe is not as knowledgable as the others. I ended up going to lecture 3 times and just watched Esselman's lectures. I got an AB in the class (3.5). Stowe does not explain concepts in a clear manner the way his colleagues do. Overall do not recommend if you can take esselman.
Dr Stowe is so funny, teaches ochem well.

He's a solid professor, explains everything that you need to know in a clear manner, the exams are fair and you should be well prepared if you do all the work. Nothing to complain about, he taught the challenging material in an understandable way, you need to know the foundations of the material to do well, not memorization.

Organic Chemistry is hard. He was a fine choice for a professor. Doesn't make you memorize pKa values or nomenclature which was nice. This sem he is part of the team taught lectures so he presents the same material/slides as the others. I don't really have much to praise or complain about.
